channel.title: Wait?
channel.description:
I am trying to make my program wait a certin amout of loops by have a integer and incresing it every time till it get to a certin number and then does somthing.
example [code] begin randomwait:= randomwait+1 if randomwait=300then begin randomwait:=0 randomtalk(); end; end.[/code]
It doesnt work does anyone know why?

item.title: Wait?
item.dc:creator: @exps35 exps35
item.description:
@exps35 wrote:

Nah. I only script on and off, and I’m not that active in keeping my knowledge up. Helping in here is just something to do when I’m bored, as nobody else ever posts in here anyways. I don’t need any credit. I’m just trying to help you learn a bit, because thats how I roll

Read full topic

item.title: Wait?
item.dc:creator: @Crazy_Cat Crazy Cat
item.description:
@Crazy_Cat wrote:

It didnt work because the whole script waited until the time past. I got it to work thought by doing this.

procedure writestuff; begin if(timefrommark(time)>60000)then begin randomtalk; marktime(time); end; end;

since the procedure ‘writestuff’ is in the main loop it still checks every time if its time to say somthing but it doesnt stop the loop. By the way do you want me to give you credit in the script you helped a lot, to bad I cant give you rep points if only there was a mod…

Read full topic

item.title: Wait?
item.dc:creator: @exps35 exps35
item.description:
@exps35 wrote:

It should look like this in a script

[code]program New;
{.include srl/srl.scar}

var
time:integer;
procedure writestuff;
begin
marktime(time);
repeat
wait(100);
until(timefrommark(time)>3000)
writeln(‘ye’);
end;

begin
repeat
writestuff;
doOtherstuff;
SomeMoreStuff;
OneLastThing;
until(false)
end.[/code]

And remember this is learning purposes. There are much easier ways of doing this if you just want to wait in between talks.

Read full topic

item.title: Wait?

but I put my procedure in a loop so it does chech every time right?

item.title: Wait?
item.dc:creator: @exps35 exps35
item.description:
@exps35 wrote:

OHHH I forgot to put in timefrommark. Sorry, I rarely use that (but lately I’ve shown people how to, and didn’t tell them that). Woops.

Just change your code to:

Procedure WaitForStuff;
begin
marktime(time);
  repeat
    wait(100);
  until(timefrommark(time)>3000)
RandomTalk;
end;

You do this because in your script, it checks to see the time, and if its not 3000 then it quits. you have to make the script wait and keep checking the time UNTIL it reaches the specified time.

Sorry if I sux at teaching :X

Read full topic

item.title: Wait?
item.dc:creator: @exps35 exps35
item.description:
@exps35 wrote:

60 seconds times 5 is 300. Under the constants, put 300 (normally it would be 300000, but I made the script multiply your number by 1,000).

item.title: Wait?
item.dc:creator: @exps35 exps35
item.description:
@exps35 wrote:

[code]
program Whatever;
{.include SRL/SRL.scar}

const
TimeToWait = 32; //Time in Seconds to wait between StuffToSay
var
RandomWait:Integer;

Procedure WaitForStuff;
begin
MarkTime(RandomWait);
repeat
wait(100);
until(RandomWait>TimeToWait*1000)
RandomTalk();
end;

Begin
Repeat
WaitForStuff
Until();
end.[/code]

I wrote this as close to your original as possible, because I don’t exactly know what you’re using it for. I made it a procedure and left your main loop open, so you can add on to it.

Read full topic

item.title: Wait?
item.dc:creator: @exps35 exps35
item.description:
@exps35 wrote:

begin repeat randomwait:= randomwait+1; until(Randomwait=300) if randomwait=300then begin randomwait:=0 randomtalk(); end; end.
I think that will work for what you are trying to do.

Just wondering, are you wanting to wait for a certain number of loops, or do you want a specified time? Loops can vary in speed, while time will remain constant.

Read full topic
